Chief Complaint: Overnight pressors were weaned to 1.5 levo, 0.3 neo,
   received 3L LR with good hemodynamic response. Patient became more
   awake, alert and responsive. C/o headache, had no evidence of
   neurological symptoms, and resolved with increased fentanyl.
   24 Hour Events:

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.3/150.0/1.4, ALT / AST:129/208, Alk Phos
   / T Bili:70/0.3, Ca++:6.7 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL, PO4:5.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   pressors, intubated, heparin gtt.
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden, CT scan shows RV dilatation and multiple bilateral PEs. TTE
   showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function intact. Pt is
   likely preload dependent and is responding well to continued IVF.
   Dobutamine was given initially, but pt had tachycardia and decreased
   BPs in response. On levo and neo.
   - would favor IVF boluses to maintain BP rather than pressors
   - wean pressors for goal MAPs >65
   - cortisol pending
   .
   #. Large P.E s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy which ended at 925. Currently on heparin
   gtt. No e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - monitor coags, Fibrinogen, FDP for e/o DIC
   - transfuse 1 unit PRBCs
   - check Hct q4hrs
   - guaiac all stools
   .
   #. s/p PEA arrest: Had 3 episodes, likely [**3-1**] PEs. No e/o cerebral
   ischemic injury although difficult to judge with intubation/sedation.
   - monitor on tele, no events overnight
   .
   #. Tranaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs. ischemic
   hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.
   - monitor daily
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 1.6, unknown baseline but presumably normal. Likely
   pre-renal in setting of hypotension/hypoperfusion, but could also have
   ATN from same etiology.
   - monitor response with fluids and improved BP
   - urine lytes pending
   .
   #. HCT drop: Patient had Hct drop despite receiving 2 units PRBC, in
   setting of t-PA and supratherapeutic PTT of >150 on heparin gtt.
   Patient did have visible bleeding from bleed surigical sites, diffuse
   oozing and BRBPR, but there is still concern for occult blood loss with
   this degree of Hct drop. Concern would be for RP bleed.
   - non con CT to r/o RP bleed
   - cont q4h Hct checks and transfuse for goal>30
   .
   #. AMS: Pt noted to be unresponsive initially on examination with no
   sedation on board. At OSH she was reported to have non-focal movement
   of her upper extremities. Now alert, responsive, following commands,
   neuro exam grossly intact. Cannot yet entirely rule out brain injury
   from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, but seems reassuring at this point. Pt c/o
   headache overnight but pupils equal and reactive, headache seems to
   have resolved.
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam q4hrs specfically for pupillary
   reaction
   .
   #. ?Pneumomediastinum: On CXR portable there appears to be trace air in
   the mediastinum, suspect this was artifact and not seen on today
s CXR.
   .
   #. ?Catheter wire: On CXR portable there appears to be an artifact that
   could be a threading wire, unclear if this is external or internal
   though on my check after CXR read there appears to be no external wire.
   Oblique view showed artifact had relocated to below the diaphragm,
   highly unlikely that this is internal. Repeat this AM continues to show
   this foreign object vs. artifact.
   - look at scout images for ab CT
   - consider lateral film
   .
   #. s/p intubation: Pt had good p02 on Fi02 50% and weaned down to 40%
   this AM. Patient has good respiratory drive and mental status would
   likely support extubation.  Will keep intubated today to allow more
   aggressive hydration.
   - PSV trial, maintain patient at most comfortable settings
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Will try to obtain OSH
   records regarding pt's recent infectious course. Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA.
   - cont levaquin for prior wound infection course
   - D/C vanco since prior wound cx grew GNR
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with pressure dressing over surgical site
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: initiate  TF via  OGT, replete electrolytes (check ionized
   Ca daily with ABG)
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2129-1-24**] 11:49 AM
   16 Gauge - [**2129-1-24**] 11:50 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2129-1-24**] 01:30 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2129-1-25**] 12:16 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: IV ppi
   VAP:  VAP bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 2084**] (HCP/Husband): [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10721**] and
   patient
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, which led to a PEA arrest. She was resuscitated and intubated, and was given thrombolytic therapy for a large pulmonary embolism (PE). She is currently on pressors and has been weaned off dobutamine due to tachycardia and decreased blood pressure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 101/54 mmHg, and her heart rate is 109 bpm.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 14, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.
* Neurological status: The patient is awake, alert, and responsive, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 17.8 K/uL, hemoglobin is 11.5 g/dL, and platelet count is 382 K/uL. Her liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 129 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 208 U/L.

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

1. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to her PE burden, and she is responding well to continued intravenous fluids (IVF).
2. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: The patient has a large PE and is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) recurrence.
3. s/p PEA arrest: The patient had three episodes of PEA arrest, which may have caused cerebral ischemic injury, although this is difficult to determine with intubation and sedation.
4. Tranaminitis: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may be due to hepatic congestion or ischemic hepatitis.
5. HCT drop: The patient's hemoglobin concentration has dropped, which may be due to occult blood loss or bleeding from surgical sites.
6.?Pneumomediastinum: There is a possibility of pneumomediastinum on the patient's chest X-ray, although this is unclear.
7.?Catheter wire: There is a possibility of a catheter wire artifact on the patient's chest X-ray, although this is unclear.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue IVF boluses to maintain blood pressure.
2. Wean pressors for a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) of >65 mmHg.
3. Monitor coagulation studies, fibrinogen, and FDP for evidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
4. Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and monitor hemoglobin concentration.
5. Check Hct every 4 hours and transfuse as needed.
6. Continue heparin gtt with a goal partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 60-80 seconds.
7. Monitor neurologic status every 4 hours and report any changes.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding risk and transfuse as needed.
10. Obtain OSH records regarding the patient's recent infectious course.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Nutrition: Initiate total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and replete electrolytes.
2. Glycemic control: Monitor blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
3. Lines: Monitor the patient's IV lines and arterial line for signs of infection or malfunction.
4. Prophylaxis: Administer heparin gtt for DVT prophylaxis, IV ppi for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and VAP bundle for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis.
5. Communication: Communicate with the patient's family and healthcare providers regarding her condition and plan of care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent recent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a PEA arrest. She was resuscitated and intubated, and has since been receiving pressors, intubated, and heparin infusion. The patient has been improving, with increased hemodynamic stability, and is now more awake and alert.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is at risk of developing further cardiogenic shock due to her underlying cardiac condition, multiple bilateral pulmonary emboli, and continued preload dependence.
2. Large Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a large PE, which may lead to further complications, such as cardiogenic shock, hypotension, or even death.
3. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): The patient is at risk of developing DIC due to her recent thrombolytic therapy and ongoing heparin infusion.
4. Brain Injury: Although the patient is currently alert and responsive, she may have suffered brain injury due to hypoxia or hypoperfusion during her PEA arrest, which could lead to long-term cognitive or neurological deficits.
5. Pneumomediastinum: The patient has a suspected pneumomediastinum, which may require further evaluation and management to prevent complications.
6. Catheter-Related Complications: The patient has a multi-lumen catheter, which may be associated with complications such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or catheter occlusion.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, which may lead to respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or respiratory failure.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of infection, which may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or organ failure.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and addressing any potential complications promptly to prevent further deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest and subsequent thrombolytic therapy for a large pulmonary embolism (PE). She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. Her blood pressure is controlled with levo and neo pressors, and she is receiving IV fluids and heparin. She has a history of breast reduction surgery and infection, which may be related to her current condition.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase, indicating potential cardiac and muscle damage. Her coagulation profile is abnormal, with elevated D-dimer and fibrinogen levels, suggesting a hypercoagulable state.

The patient's neurological examination is grossly intact, with normal pupillary reactions and preserved sensation and strength. However, she reported a headache overnight, which has since resolved.

Potential medical complications:

1. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen if her PEs are not adequately treated, and she may require further interventions such as thrombectomy or pulmonary embolectomy.
2. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: The patient's large PE may continue to cause hypoxia and respiratory failure, and she may require further anticoagulation therapy.
3. s/p PEA arrest: The patient's PEA arrest may have caused end-organ ischemia and hypoperfusion, leading to potential long-term sequelae such as cognitive impairment or stroke.
4. AMS: The patient's altered mental status may be due to hypoxia, hypoperfusion, or other underlying conditions, and she requires close monitoring for signs of worsening neurological function.
5.?Pneumomediastinum: The patient's CXR shows a possible artifact that may indicate pneumomediastinum, which could be a sign of respiratory failure or other complications.
6.?Catheter wire: The patient's CXR shows an artifact that may be a threading wire, which could be a sign of catheter-related complications.
7. s/p intubation: The patient's intubation may have caused respiratory complications, and she requires close monitoring for signs of worsening respiratory function.
8. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: The patient's breast surgery reduction may have caused an infection, which may be related to her current condition and requires further evaluation and treatment.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications, including cardiac, respiratory, neurological, and infectious complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has already experienced a PEA arrest and is at risk of another arrest due to persistent cardiogenic shock and pulmonary embolism.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The development of left-sided effusion and consolidation increases the risk of respiratory complications.
3. Shock: The patient is experiencing cardiogenic shock, which can lead to hypotension, organ dysfunction, and decreased tissue perfusion.
4. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a massive pulmonary embolism, which can lead to further respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient has had significant improvement in neurologic status, but the use of sedatives and analgesics may mask underlying cognitive impairment.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have risen to 2.1, indicating acute kidney injury. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and decreased clearance of waste products.
7. DVT and Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a high risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism due to immobility and underlying medical conditions.
8. VAP and Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and sepsis due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and underlying medical conditions.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's use of sedatives and analgesics may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as constipation, nausea, and vomiting.
10. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of developing infections.

To address these complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. This includes ongoing assessment of cardiovascular and respiratory status, management of shock and fluid balance, and monitoring of renal function. Additionally, the patient requires prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer, and close monitoring for signs of VAP and sepsis.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery complicated by infection, which led to a PEA arrest. She underwent thrombolytic therapy and is currently on pressors, intubated, and receiving heparin drips. The patient's condition has been stable, but she continues to experience hypotension, which responds well to fluids. She has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued hypotension and need for pressors: The patient's hypotension is likely due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and may require ongoing management with pressors.
2. ATN progression: The patient's ATN is likely to worsen if she continues to experience hypotension and hypoperfusion, which may require further management with renal consult and dose adjustment of medications.
3. Bleeding complications: The patient has a history of bleeding complications, including bleeding at the surgical site after thrombolytic therapy, and may be at risk for further bleeding complications.
4. Infection: The patient's infection may worsen if she is not properly managed, which may lead to sepsis and organ failure.
5. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen if she does not receive adequate management, which may lead to cardiac arrest and death.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen if she experiences further hypoxia or hypoperfusion, which may lead to brain injury or death.
7. Thrombotic complications: The patient's thrombolytic therapy may lead to thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), which may worsen her condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust pressors as necessary.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications accordingly.
3. Continue to manage the patient's bleeding complications and monitor for signs of further bleeding.
4. Continue to manage the patient's infection and monitor for signs of sepsis.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust management accordingly.
6. Consider consulting a renal specialist to further manage the patient's ATN.
7. Consider consulting a cardiologist to further manage the patient's cardiogenic shock.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's continued requirement for pressors and her hypokinetic, dilated RV on TTE suggest that she may be at risk for cardiogenic shock.
2. Large Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's recent thrombolytic therapy and CT scan findings suggest that she may have a large PE, which can lead to further complications such as pulmonary hypertension and right heart strain.
3. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's increasing creatinine and FeNa levels suggest that she may be developing ATN, which can be caused by hypoperfusion and hypotension.
4. Anemia: The patient's falling Hct levels despite transfusions suggest that she may be experiencing bleeding, which can be caused by a variety of factors including surgical site bleeding, PE, or ATN.
5. Tranaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes suggest that she may be experiencing liver injury, which can be caused by hypoperfusion, hypotension, or right heart strain.
6. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's increasing creatinine levels and need for renal dose medications suggest that she may be experiencing AKI, which can be caused by ATN, hypoperfusion, or other factors.
7. Brain Injury: The patient's recent PEA arrest and hypoxia/hypoperfusion may have caused brain injury, which can lead to long-term cognitive and functional impairment.
8. Sepsis: The patient's recent infection and antibiotic therapy suggest that she may be at risk for sepsis, which can lead to further complications such as organ dysfunction and death.
9. Catheter-Related Complications: The patient's portable CXR showing an artifact that could be a threading wire suggests that there may be a catheter-related complication, such as a catheter-related bloodstream infection or catheter malfunction.

The patient's treatment plan should focus on addressing these potential complications, including:

1. Managing her cardiogenic shock with pressors and fluids.
2. Treating her large PE with anticoagulation therapy and considering thrombolytic therapy.
3. Managing her ATN with renally dose medications and considering renal consult.
4. Treating her anemia with transfusions and considering hemolysis labs.
5. Managing her tranaminitis with liver function tests and considering liver consult.
6. Managing her AKI with renally dose medications and considering dialysis.
7. Monitoring her brain function and considering neuro consult.
8. Monitoring for sepsis and considering antibiotic therapy.
9. Monitoring for catheter-related complications and considering catheter removal or replacement.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. She has been receiving mechanical ventilation and pressor support to manage her hypotension. Her mental status has improved significantly over the past two days, and she has shown good tolerance of spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) with minimal pressure support. Her current vital signs include a temperature of 38°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 107/54 mmHg. Her respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Her abdomen is soft and non-tender, and she has bilateral lower extremity edema.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's kidney function is concerning, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25.1 mg/dL. ATN is a potential complication of cardiac arrest and sepsis, and the patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels suggest that she may be at risk for this condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels suggest that she may be septic. Sepsis is a potential complication of cardiac arrest and sepsis, and the patient's elevated WBC and CRP levels suggest that she may be at risk for this condition.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a potential complication of cardiac arrest and sepsis. Her respiratory rate is elevated, and her oxygen saturation is decreased, suggesting that she may be at risk for respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and sepsis may lead to cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction, cardiomyopathy, or arrhythmias.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's abdominal pain and distension may be a sign of gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or ischemia.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and decreased level of consciousness may be a sign of neurological complications such as cerebral edema, infarction, or hemorrhage.
7. Thromboembolic Complications: The patient's elevated D-dimer level and decreased platelet count suggest that she may be at risk for thromboembolic complications such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

These are the potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition and medical history.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent a bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a PEA arrest, which was successfully treated with thrombolytics. She was intubated and placed on pressors, but has since been weaned off pressors and extubated. She has been experiencing anemia, with a falling Hct despite transfusions, and has ecchymosis in her left groin. Her cardiac status is complex, with a large PE and cardiogenic shock, but she has been responding well to IVF. She has also developed ATN, transaminitis, and may have AMS. Her wound infection is being managed with antibiotics and wound care.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Hemothorax:** The patient's CXR shows stable left lower lobe atelectasis and pleural effusion with moderately severe interstitial edema, which could be a sign of hemothorax.
2. **Bleeding:** The patient's anemia and ecchymosis in her left groin suggest that she may be bleeding internally, which could be a sign of a more serious condition.
3. **Cardiogenic Shock:** The patient's cardiogenic shock could worsen if her cardiac function does not improve, which could lead to further complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or even death.
4. **Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN):** The patient's ATN could worsen if her renal function does not improve, which could lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or even death.
5. **Transaminitis:** The patient's transaminitis could worsen if her liver function does not improve, which could lead to further complications such as jaundice, ascites, or even death.
6. **AMS:** The patient's AMS could worsen if her neurologic status does not improve, which could lead to further complications such as seizures, coma, or even death.
7. **Wound Infection:** The patient's wound infection could worsen if not properly managed, which could lead to further complications such as sepsis, abscess formation, or even death.
8. **DVT:** The patient's heparin drip may not be adequate to prevent DVT, which could lead to further complications such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's Hct and transfuse as necessary to maintain a Hct > 25.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust her treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust her treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's wound infection with antibiotics and wound care.
6. Consider consulting a renal specialist to further manage the patient's ATN.
7. Consider consulting a neurologist to further manage the patient's AMS.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has poor inspiratory effort and fluid overload, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure. She is being weaned off pressors and is on incentive spirometry, chest physical therapy, and diuresis.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have been increasing, and her urine output has been decreasing. She has been diagnosed with ATN, likely caused by hypoperfusion/hypotension.
4. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is in cardiogenic shock, likely due to her large pulmonary embolism (PE). She has been treated with thrombolytics and is currently on heparin gtt.
5. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to hepatic congestion or ischemic hepatitis.
6. Catheter wire: There is an artifact on the CXR that could be a threading wire, but it is unclear if it is external or internal.
7. Infection: The patient has an infection at the right breast surgical site, which may be related to the prolonged hospital stay and ICU admission.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Anemia: Continue to monitor Hct levels and transfuse as needed. Consider CT scans to determine if there is a thigh bleed.
2. Respiratory Failure: Continue to wean off pressors and diurese as needed. Consider renal consult if Cr worsens.
3. AKI: Continue to monitor Cr and lytes daily. Consider renal consult if Cr worsens.
4. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Continue to monitor BP and adjust fluid boluses or PRBCs as needed. Consider diuresis if BP remains stable.
5. Transaminitis: Continue to monitor liver enzymes and consider renal consult if Cr worsens.
6. Catheter wire: Repeat films to confirm the absence of a foreign object.
7. Infection: Continue antibiotics and monitor for signs of infection.

Summary:

The patient, a 51-year-old female, is in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) after undergoing bilateral breast reduction surgery, which was complicated by an infection. She had a PEA arrest and was treated with thrombolytics, which led to a large pulmonary embolism (PE). She was intubated and received pressors, but was weaned off them and extubated. The patient has been experiencing anemia, with a falling hemoglobin level despite transfusions. She has also been experiencing obstructive cardiogenic shock, likely due to the PE burden. The patient's creatinine level is increasing, suggesting acute tubular necrosis (ATN) caused by hypoperfusion/hypotension. She has also been experiencing transaminitis, which is trending down. The patient's neurological examination is grossly intact, but she cannot be ruled out for brain injury from hypoxia/hypoperfusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin level is still falling, and it is unclear whether the bleeding is due to the surgical site, PE, or other causes.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and she may require further treatment to improve her cardiac output.
3. Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and she may require further treatment to manage her kidney function.
4. Neurological complications: The patient may be at risk for neurological complications due to her hypoxia/hypoperfusion episode.
5. Infection: The patient's surgical site is still at risk for infection, and she may require further treatment to prevent or manage any infections.
6. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE is a significant risk factor for further complications, including recurrent PE or pulmonary hypertension.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require further transfusions or other treatments to manage her hemoglobin level.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemoglobin level and transfuse as needed to maintain a hemoglobin level >25.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac function with fluid boluses and vasopressors as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and manage her kidney function with medications and fluids as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological examination and consider further testing or consultation if concerns arise.
5. Continue to manage the patient's surgical site with antibiotics and wound care as needed.
6. Consider further testing or consultation to evaluate the patient's pulmonary embolism and potential for recurrent PE or pulmonary hypertension.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour post-extubation patient who was previously intubated and ventilated. They were extubated in the morning and did well post-extubation. However, they experienced bilious emesis at 2 am, which was managed with zofran and compazine. The patient's hemoglobin levels have been decreasing, and they have received 2 units of packed red blood cells. The patient's chest X-ray shows stable left lower lobe atelectasis and pleural effusion with increased pulmonary edema.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 155/57 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen via nasal cannula at 2L and have a SpO2 of 100%. The patient's respiratory support includes invasive ventilation, which was stopped 24 hours ago.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.4-8.6 K/μL, hemoglobin level of 22.2-26.3 g/dL, and platelet count of 119-157 K/μL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an ALT of 53 U/L and AST of 59 U/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's chest X-ray shows moderate to severe interstitial edema, which may be indicative of pulmonary embolism.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's chest X-ray shows increased pulmonary edema, which may be indicative of ARDS.
3. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be indicative of sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin levels have been decreasing, which may be indicative of bleeding.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are low, which may be indicative of anemia.
6. Pain management: The patient's pain levels are not well-controlled, which may lead to increased discomfort and potential complications.
7. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may be indicative of hypotension.
8. Tissue perfusion alteration: The patient's vital signs suggest altered tissue perfusion, which may be indicative of decreased perfusion to organs.
9. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest is a significant risk factor for potential complications.
10. Infection: The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, which may be indicative of infection.

Based on the patient's medical history and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory support. The patient's pain levels should be closely monitored and managed, and their bleeding should be carefully assessed and managed. Additionally, the patient's risk of pulmonary embolism, ARDS, sepsis, and anemia should be closely monitored and managed accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female admitted with pulmonary embolus and PEA arrest, now extubated but with residual issues of renal failure, anemia, pain, and persistent memory deficits.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 94 bpm (91-118 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 145/56 mmHg (84-155/57 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 16 inspirations per minute (15-19 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Overweight/obese
* Normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat
* Cardiovascular: S1 and S2 sounds are normal, but distant
* Respiratory/chest: Symmetric expansion, dullness to percussion, wheezes, and diminished breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft and distended
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema (2+), left lower extremity edema (2+), and significant left-sided ecchymosis in the femoral area consistent with a substantial hematoma
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, and has perseverative questioning

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 123 K/uL
* Platelet count: 157 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.9 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.1 g/dL
* LDH: 494 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.9 mg/dL

Imaging studies reveal:

* CXR: Decreased lung volumes, mild interstitial edema

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to immobility and the need for incentive spirometry.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia is concerning, and the cause is unknown. A CT scan of the thigh/groin area is recommended to investigate potential blood loss.
3. Renal failure: The patient has likely developed acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and pre-renal insult with myocardial dysfunction and arrest. The goal is to follow urine output and achieve negative fluid balance.
4. Altered memory: The patient's altered memory is likely due to a transient anoxic insult with arrest. Behavioral changes may occur.
5. Pain control: The patient's pain is managed with as-needed Dilaudid.

The plan for the patient's care includes:

1. Respiratory support: Continue incentive spirometry and nebs to support respiratory function.
2. Anemia management: Continue transfusions as needed based on 8-hour intervals, and aim for a hemoglobin level of 24 or higher with evidence of acute loss.
3. Renal failure management: Follow urine output and aim for negative fluid balance.
4. Pain control: Use as-needed Dilaudid to manage pain.
5. ICU care: Provide nutrition as tolerated, and consider moving to oral nutrition once bowel function returns. Monitor for signs of stress ulceration and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient's disposition is ICU, and code status is full code. The total time spent with the patient is 45 minutes.

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest x3
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   heparin gtt, now of pressors and extubated.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt continues to have falling Hct despite transfusions. Source
   of bleeding unclear- unlikely to be all explained by surgical site, CT
   ab neg for RP bleed.   No signs of hemolysis.  Patient does have
   ecchymosis in left groin (line placed in rt groin).
   - cont q6 Hct checks and transfuse for Hct<25.  Would space out Hct
   checks if next is stable.
   - CT leg not source on our read, await final read.
   - consider rescan of abdomen if Hct continues to fall
   .
   # Respiratory Failure-Patient with poor inspiratory effort and fluid
   overload.  CXR difficult to interpret this AM given
   - OOB to chair yesterday
   - PT consult
   - incentive spirometer, chest PT
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - diuresis
   .
   #. AMS: alert, responsive, following commands, neuro exam grossly
   intact.  Patient perseverative, likely with short term memory deficits
   from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, although it is unclear what her long term
   functional status will be.
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam
   - minimize sedation medications; will space out dilaudid prn
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden. TTE showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function
   intact. Pt is likely preload dependent and is responds well to IVF.
   Now weaned off of pressors, with BP low overnight secondary to pain
   medication but improved BP this morning.
   - will procede with cautious diuresis as patient is thought to be
   grossly volume overloaded,
   - if BP becomes an issue today, can give back some volume.
   .
   #. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy on [**1-24**]. Currently on heparin gtt. No
   e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - transfuse for goal Hct>30
   - monitor Hct
   - guaiac all stools
   - hold off on transition to coumadin until Hct stable
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: FeNA 0.6. Cr continues to increase after hydration and improved
   hemodynamics, more consistent with ATN caused by
   hypoperfusion/hypotension. CT scan also showed e/o ATN bilaterally.
   Cre down slightly today, with BUN up slightly, this may complicate
   diuresis.
   - renally dose meds
   - trend Cr and lytes daily
   - consider renal consult if Cr worsens
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs.
   ischemic hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.  Trending
   down today.
   - continues to trend down, this along with better renal function may
   indicate better forward flow.
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA. Plastics following.
   - appreciate plastics recs
   - course of levaquin completed
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with surgibra/pressure dressing over surgical site
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: clear fluids, will advance to full as tolerated
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   -PICC placed, CVL d/c
d and plan for A-line d/c

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery complicated by infection, pulmonary embolism (PE), and cardiogenic shock. She has been treated with thrombolytics, heparin, and pressors. Her current condition is stable, but she continues to have falling hemoglobin levels despite transfusions, and her creatinine levels are increasing. She has also developed transaminitis, and her liver function tests are trending down.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin levels are falling despite transfusions, and the source of bleeding is unclear. Further investigation is needed to identify the cause of bleeding and prevent further complications.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to her PE burden, and she is being treated with heparin and pressors. However, her blood pressure is still low, and she may require further treatment to maintain adequate perfusion.
3. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and her CT scan shows evidence of ATN bilaterally. Further monitoring and treatment are needed to prevent further kidney damage.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's liver function tests are trending down, and her transaminitis is likely due to hepatic congestion or right heart strain. Further monitoring is needed to ensure that her liver function does not deteriorate further.
5. Infection: The patient's breast reduction surgery was complicated by infection, and she has developed ecchymosis at the surgical site. Further monitoring and treatment are needed to prevent further complications.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient has poor inspiratory effort and fluid overload, and she requires respiratory support. Further treatment is needed to improve her respiratory function and prevent further complications.
7. Neurological Deficits: The patient has perseverative behavior and likely has short-term memory deficits due to hypoxia and hypoperfusion. Further monitoring is needed to assess her neurological function and prevent further complications.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemoglobin levels and transfuse as necessary to maintain a hemoglobin level of 25 or higher.
2. Continue to treat the patient's cardiogenic shock with heparin and pressors, and monitor her blood pressure closely to ensure adequate perfusion.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and treat her ATN with diuresis and renally dosed medications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and treat her transaminitis with supportive care.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and treat with antibiotics and surgical debridement as necessary.
6. Continue to provide respiratory support and monitor the patient's respiratory function closely.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological function and provide supportive care as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who had a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a PEA arrest. She was treated with thrombolytics and is currently on heparin drip. She has a large PE, anemia, and is in cardiogenic shock. Her labs show a rising creatinine, suggesting possible ATN, and she has transaminitis. She is on pressors, extubated, and is receiving diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hemorrhage: The patient's anemia and ecchymosis in the left groin suggest a possible bleeding disorder. Further evaluation is needed to determine the source of bleeding.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to her large PE and hypokinetic, dilated RV. She requires careful management of her fluid status and blood pressure.
3. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's rising creatinine and BUN suggest possible ATN caused by hypoperfusion/hypotension. Close monitoring of her renal function is necessary.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is likely due to hepatic congestion or ischemic hepatitis. Close monitoring of her liver function is necessary.
5. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to her immobility and recent surgery. Prophylaxis with heparin drip is necessary.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and recent surgery make her susceptible to pneumonia. Close monitoring of her respiratory status is necessary.
7. Sepsis: The patient's infection and recent surgery make her susceptible to sepsis. Close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory values is necessary.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's recent surgery and possible ATN make her susceptible to gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring of her stool output and guaiac testing are necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit levels closely and transfuse as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiogenic shock with careful fluid management and blood pressure control.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider a renal consult if her creatinine levels worsen.
4. Continue to manage the patient's transaminitis with close monitoring of her liver function.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider a respiratory consult if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely for signs of sepsis.
7. Monitor the patient's stool output and guaiac testing closely for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU following a prolonged cardiac arrest (PEA arrest) attributed to bilateral pulmonary emboli. The patient remains extubated and off vasopressors. The patient's main complaints include generalized skin/body "soreness" and chest pain (area of CPR) and upper back pain (chronic).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure of 175/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's respiratory support includes oxygen delivery device none, and ABG results are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, and the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. The patient's neurological examination is normal, with no signs of sedation or paralysis.

Laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. The patient's coagulation profile shows an elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), indicating ongoing coagulopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pulmonary embolism recurrence: Given the patient's history of bilateral pulmonary emboli, there is a risk of recurrence, which could lead to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of respiratory failure and ongoing respiratory support indicate a risk of further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Renal failure: The patient's history of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and ongoing fluid overload increase the risk of further renal failure, which could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Infection: The patient's history of incision infections and ongoing respiratory support increase the risk of further infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's ongoing coagulopathy and history of femoral central line insertion increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as hematoma or hemorrhage.

Based on these findings, the patient requires close monitoring and ongoing medical management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest due to bilateral pulmonary emboli. He has been extubated and is off vasopressors. The patient is complaining of generalized skin and body soreness, chest pain (related to chest compressions), and upper back pain (chronic).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 103 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 175/65 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96%. He is receiving heparin sodium infusion and pantoprazole (Protonix) for anticoagulation and stress ulcer prophylaxis, respectively.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. His liver enzymes, including alkaline phosphatase and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), are elevated. His electrolyte levels, including potassium, sodium, and chloride, are within normal limits.

The patient has a history of bilateral pulmonary emboli, which is a potential medical complication that can arise from immobility following surgery. He is at risk for further blood loss due to his femoral central line and may require additional transfusions.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for further respiratory complications due to his recent cardiac arrest and pulmonary emboli. He is also at risk for further cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Pulmonary embolism: The patient is at risk for further pulmonary emboli due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and central line.
3. Renal failure: The patient is at risk for further renal failure due to his recent cardiac arrest and ATN.
4. Anemia: The patient is at risk for further anemia due to his ongoing blood loss and potential need for additional transfusions.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his central line and recent surgery.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his recent cardiac arrest and pulmonary emboli.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias due to his recent cardiac arrest and underlying medical conditions.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest attributed to massive bilateral pulmonary emboli, which was treated with thrombolysis. He was recently transferred back to the ICU for management of worsening anemia and acute GI/GU bleed. The patient has a history of immobility following surgery, which is a predisposing condition for pulmonary emboli. He has also had a breast reduction surgery complicated by incision infections, which is being monitored by Plastic Surgery.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Acute GI/GU bleed
* Anemia attributed to acute blood loss
* Concerns for GI or GU blood loss, ishemic bowel, and hemolysis
* Echymosis in the chest, arms, and right groin
* Nausea attributed to narcotics and other medications
* Chest pain attributed to chest compressions (CPR)
* Back pain, upper, chronic
* Fluid overload from resuscitation
* Poor nutritional intake
* Fever, no tachycardia, no tachypnea

Assessment and Plan:

* ANEMIA: attributed to acute blood loss. Plan to monitor serial Hct and maintain Hct >24.
* GI/GU BLEED: plan to check NGT lavage to assess for UGI bleeding source and monitor serial abd exam.
* PULMONARY EMBOLI: hold anticoagulation pending evaluation.
* RENAL FAILURE: slow recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
* NAUSEA: monitor symptoms and abdominal exam and provide symptomatic relief.
* CHEST PAIN: symptomatic relief.
* BACK PAIN: continue medications to optimize pain management.
* FLUIDS: goal net negative 2 L over the next 24 hours.
* BREAST REDUCTION SURGERY: monitored by Plastic Surgery.
* NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT: PO, but poor intake.
* ACTIVITY: encourage OOB to chair (with assist).

Potential Medical Complications:

* GI/GU bleed leading to hemorrhagic shock
* Ishemic bowel leading to bowel obstruction or perforation
* Hemolysis leading to hemolytic anemia
* Pulmonary emboli leading to pulmonary hypertension or chronic pulmonary embolism
* Renal failure leading to chronic kidney disease
* Fluid overload leading to congestive heart failure or respiratory failure
* Nausea and vomiting leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances
* Chest pain leading to cardiac arrhythmias or myocardial infarction
* Back pain leading to chronic pain syndrome or spinal cord compression.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 51F s/p recent PEA arrest from massive PE now
   presenting to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] in ther setting of falling HCTs and BRBPR in the
   setting of a Heparin gtt.
   .
   #: HCT Drop: Pt remains hemodynamically stable with SBPs in 160s. This
   AM she had two more bloody bowel movements, and despite transfusions
   she appearrs to have stagnated at a hct of 27.  At this point her blood
   loss appearrs to be a combination of GI and breast.
   - Maintain access via Power PICC, attempt to gain 1 18g PIV
   - q4Hct Checks
 in agreement with GI and surgery our stated goal is 30
   in case she opens up
   - GI Consult
 refusing to scope, suggested tagged red cell scan which
   was negative.
   - CT Torso  - showed right breast hematoma, some ileal/jejunal
   thickening
   - Consider repeat tagged red cell scan with increased bleeding to
   identify source, attending-to-attending with GI
   - IV PPi
   - Type and Cross 4 units at all time pRBCs
   - discuss IVC filter with IR
   - continue heparin for now, if hemodynamically unstable reverse with
   protamine.
   .
   #: PE: PT remains hemodynmically stable. Has been on therapeutic
   Heparin gtt since admission. Would like to get IVC filter today.
   - continuing heparin for now
   - IVC filter
     .
   #: [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 2.0 today from 2.4 yesterday, unclear baseline but was 1.6
   on admission which peaked at 3.0. Pt continues to make good UOP. Likely
   ATN following hypotensive event.
   - Cont to trend
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   #: Hypertension: Pt on Lisinopril 20mg as outpatient. Have held
   antihypertensives while in house given given Hct drop and PE. Continue
   to trend.
   - Restart ACEi at lower dose once Hct stabilizes and renal function
   improves
   - Will tolerate higher blood pressures in the setting of her GI bleed
   .
   #  AMS: Pt remains AOx3 with neuro some likely with short term memory
   deficits from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, sedation.   Concern for some ICU
   delerium at night
   - Continue to monitor and trend
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam
   - minimize sedation medications; will space out dilaudid prn
   - haldol PRN for agitation
   .
   #: Bilateral Breast Reduction Sugery: Being following by plastics. Per
   report hematoma at right breast.
   - Rt breast wound packed w/ surgicell and gauze
   - Compressive dressing w/ 4x4s fan folded Kerlix and tape. Then two
   kerlix rolls applied over medial aspect Rt Breast and abdominal binder
   applied
   - NS WTD dressing to wounds [**Hospital1 **]
   - Cont Levaquin
   FEN: KVO/Replete PRN/Advance to
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management with narcotics
   ACCESS: PICC
   CODE STATUS: Full

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a recent PEA arrest due to a massive pulmonary embolism (PE). She is currently receiving heparin infusions and has been diagnosed with bleeding from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and breast. Despite transfusions, her hematocrit (HCT) has stabilized at 27%. The patient is hemodynamically stable, but has ongoing GI bleeding and a right breast hematoma. She has a history of hypertension, and her blood pressure is being closely monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. GI bleeding: The patient's ongoing GI bleeding is a significant concern, and it is essential to identify the source of the bleeding to prevent further complications.
2. Breast hematoma: The patient's right breast hematoma is also a concern, and it is essential to monitor it closely to prevent further complications.
3. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT): The patient is receiving heparin infusions, and there is a risk of developing HIT, which could lead to further bleeding complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension and hypoperfusion.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 96%, but there is a risk of developing respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and is at risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures, due to her underlying medical condition and the need for sedation and analgesia.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis, due to her underlying medical condition and the need for invasive procedures.
8. Bleeding complications: The patient is at risk of developing further bleeding complications, such as intracranial bleeding or bleeding from the breast or GI tract.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and breast hematoma closely to prevent further complications.
2. Consider repeating the tagged red cell scan to identify the source of the bleeding.
3. Continue to administer heparin infusions to prevent further clotting, but monitor for signs of HIT.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely to prevent further kidney damage.
5. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory function closely to prevent respiratory failure.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological function closely to prevent neurological complications.
7. Monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count closely to prevent infection.
8. Consider transferring the patient to a higher-level care facility if further management is required.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU following a recent PEA arrest from massive pulmonary embolism (PE). She is currently hemodynamically stable, but has been experiencing a decline in hemoglobin levels and is presenting with bright red blood per rectum (BRBPR).

The patient's medical history includes a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery, and she has a history of hypertension and is currently taking Lisinopril 20mg as an outpatient. She also has a history of anaphylaxis to penicillins and Macrobid.

The patient's current medications include Heparin gtt, Pantoprazole (Protonix), and Haloperidol (Haldol). She is also receiving IV fluids and has been transfused with blood products.

The patient's physical examination is notable for ecchymoses in the left upper extremity (LUE) and right upper extremity (RUE), as well as skin breakdown in the RUE. Her abdomen is distended, firm, and tender, with moderate diffuse tenderness and no guarding.

The patient's laboratory results show a decline in hemoglobin levels, with a current level of 9.6 g/dL. Her platelet count is 123 K/uL, and her white blood cell count is 8.6 K/uL. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. HCT drop: The patient's hemoglobin levels have been declining, and she has been experiencing bleeding from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and breast. Her current goal is to maintain a hemoglobin level of 30 g/dL.
2. PE: The patient has been on therapeutic Heparin gtt since admission and is currently hemodynamically stable. An IVC filter is being considered to prevent further emboli.
3. Renal function: The patient's creatinine level has been declining, and she is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) following her hypotensive event.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been elevated, and she is currently on hold for antihypertensive medications. Her blood pressure will be monitored and treated as needed.
5. Neurological status: The patient is currently awake and oriented to person, place, and time, but has some short-term memory deficits and is at risk for ICU delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further bleeding from the GI tract or breast, leading to hypovolemic shock.
2. Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) or ATN due to hypotension and nephrotoxic medications.
3. Increased risk of infection due to the patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged hospitalization.
4. Development of ICU delirium or cognitive impairment due to prolonged sedation and critical illness.
5. Increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to the patient's immobility and underlying hypercoagulable state.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with ongoing medical management. The patient has a PICC line inserted and has undergone nuclear medicine testing. They are receiving infusions of Heparin Sodium and other ICU medications, including Pantoprazole and Haloperidol. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 158/60 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy with a SpO2 of 96%. The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, and elevated white blood cell count, with a WBC count of 11.6 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding risk: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy with Heparin Sodium, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
2. Infection: The patient has a PICC line and is receiving antibiotics, which may increase the risk of infection.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is receiving Pantoprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, which may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen therapy and respiratory support may be necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation, and the patient may be at risk for respiratory failure if their respiratory status deteriorates.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's Haloperidol therapy may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, particularly QT prolongation.
6. Neurological compromise: The patient's neurological status is not well-documented, and they may be at risk for neurological compromise if their condition deteriorates.
7. Renal insufficiency: The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels, which may indicate renal insufficiency.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's laboratory results show abnormal electrolyte levels, including hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, which may indicate an electrolyte imbalance.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU following a recent pulmonary embolism (PE) and is currently experiencing a massive gastrointestinal bleed (GI). She has a history of penicillin allergy and anaphylaxis. Her current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 97 bpm (93-109 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 158/60 mmHg (126/40-180/77 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (0-29 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 27.7%

The patient has been receiving heparin infusion since admission and has been experiencing bloody bowel movements. She has also developed a right breast hematoma following bilateral breast reduction surgery. Her laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.6 K/uL
* Platelet count: 174 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 114 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L

The patient's plan includes:

* Maintaining access via Power PICC and attempting to gain an 18-gauge peripheral intravenous line
* Quarterly hemoglobin checks
* GI consultation to consider repeat tagged red cell scan with increased bleeding to identify the source of bleeding
* IV proton pump inhibitor
* Type and cross 4 units of packed red blood cells at all times
* Discussion of inferior vena cava (IVC) filter with interventional radiology
* Continuing heparin infusion for now, with plans to reverse with protamine if hemodynamically unstable

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding complications: The patient's massive GI bleed and right breast hematoma may lead to further bleeding complications, including hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's heparin infusion and bleeding may lead to coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL may indicate early signs of renal failure, which can worsen with continued bleeding and hypovolemia.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure of 158/60 mmHg may indicate hypotension, which can worsen with continued bleeding and hypovolemia.
5. Infection: The patient's bloody bowel movements and right breast hematoma may increase the risk of infection, including sepsis and organ failure.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and potential for ICU delirium may lead to neurological complications, including confusion, agitation, and seizures.
7. Respiratory complications: The patient's bloody bowel movements and right breast hematoma may lead to respiratory complications, including pneumonia and respiratory failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yof s/p PEA arrest (in field) attritubed to bilateral pulmonary
   emboli (lysis), now with acute GI bleed.
   ANEMIA -- attributed to acute blood loss.  Appears to be GI (lower
   source).  Blood loss also through breast incision sites, and at risk
   for blood loss into thigh (sight of femoral central line).  Concern for
   ishemic bowel (noted inflammation on most recent CT scan).  No evidence
   for hemolysis.  Ecchymosis (chest, arms, right groin) accounts for some
   blood loss.  Monitor serial abd exam, serial Hct, maintain Hct >28.  GI
   consultation in place.  General surgery to F/U.  Hold anticoagulation
   pending evaluation.
   GI bleed
 unclear source, but concerns include diverticular bleed,
   ischemic colitis, or tumor.  Not yet identifed site.  If persistent
   bleeding (off heparin) would proceed with repeat bleeding scan, and
   consider angiography +/- embolizattion.  GI service and Surgery
   following.
   PULMONARY EMBOLI -- s/p arrest and thrombolysis.  Predisposing
   condition of immobility following surgery.  WouldHold anticoagulation,
   resume once bleeding issue resolved.  If unable to continue
   anticoagulation, would place IVC filter (removable).
   NAUSEA
 evidence for ileus (gastric and proximal small bowel air-fluid
   level).  Unfortunately pt. self d/c
d OGT.  Will encourage pt to accept
   replacement of NGT.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN in context of PEA arrest.  Slow
   recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
   NAUSEA -- attributed to narcotics (in part), and other medications.
   Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam.  Provide symptomatic relief.
   CHEST PAIN -- attributed to chest compressions (CPR).  Symptomatic
   relief.
   BACK PAIN -- upper, chronic.  Continue medications to optimize pain

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old individual who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of GI bleed. The patient has a complex medical history, including a recent PEA arrest attributed to bilateral pulmonary emboli, which was lysed. The patient also has a history of breast reduction surgery, which was complicated by incision infections and is now experiencing bleeding complications while on heparin.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

1. GI bleed: The patient is experiencing recurrent hematochezia and blood clots via the rectum, with no evidence of hemodynamic compromise or abdominal pain. The source of the bleed is unclear, but concerns include diverticular bleed, ischemic colitis, or tumor.
2. Anemia: The patient has anemia attributed to acute blood loss, with a current Hct of 25.4%.
3. Pulmonary emboli: The patient has a history of pulmonary emboli, which was lysed, and is at risk for recurrent emboli.
4. Nausea: The patient is experiencing nausea, which is attributed to ileus and medications.
5. Renal failure: The patient has renal failure attributed to ATN in the context of PEA arrest.
6. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, which is a concern for arrest-associated encephalopathy.
7. Fluid overload: The patient is net volume overloaded from resuscitation, with a goal of net negative 2 L over the next 24 hours.
8. Breast reduction surgery: The patient's breast reduction surgery is complicated by incision infections and bleeding complications while on heparin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further bleeding: The patient is at risk for further bleeding, particularly in the context of ongoing anticoagulation therapy.
2. Pulmonary emboli: The patient is at risk for recurrent pulmonary emboli, particularly if anticoagulation therapy is not continued.
3. Renal failure progression: The patient's renal failure may progress if not managed properly.
4. Infection: The patient's incision infections and bleeding complications may lead to further infections, particularly in the context of immunosuppression.
5. Ischemic bowel: The patient's ischemic colitis may worsen if not managed properly.
6. Tumor progression: The patient's unclear source of bleeding may be related to a tumor, which may progress if not managed properly.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Monitoring of serial abdominal exams and Hct to monitor bleeding and anemia.
2. Maintenance of Hct >28%.
3. Hold anticoagulation therapy pending evaluation.
4. GI consultation and surgery follow-up.
5. Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
6. Encouragement of PO intake and OOB activity.
7. Monitoring of altered mental status and provision of symptomatic relief.
8. Management of nausea and ileus.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple complex medical conditions, including GI bleed, anemia, pulmonary emboli, nausea, renal failure, and altered mental status. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* The patient is a 51-year-old individual who suffered a pulmonary embolism (PEA) arrest and was resuscitated. They have a history of bilateral pulmonary emboli, which were lysed, and are now experiencing an acute gastrointestinal (GI) bleed.
* The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9°C (100.2°F), heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 161/65 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 93%.
* The patient has a history of anemia, attributed to acute blood loss, and is at risk for further blood loss due to the breast incision sites and the femoral central line.
* The patient's abdominal examination is soft, non-tender, and bowel sounds are present, but there is concern for ischemic bowel disease based on the recent CT scan findings.
* The patient has a history of nausea, attributed to ileus and narcotics, and is receiving symptomatic relief.
* The patient has a history of renal failure, attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the context of PEA arrest, and is expected to have a slow recovery.
* The patient has a history of chest pain, attributed to chest compressions, and back pain, which is chronic and managed with medication.
* The patient is net volume overloaded due to resuscitation and has a goal of net negative 2 liters over the next 24 hours.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Further bleeding: The patient's GI bleed is unclear in origin, and there is concern for diverticular bleed, ischemic colitis, or tumor. If the bleeding persists, the patient may require repeat bleeding scans and angiography.
2. Ischemic bowel disease: The patient's recent CT scan findings suggest inflammation in the bowel, which may be indicative of ischemic bowel disease.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is attributed to ATN, and they are expected to have a slow recovery. Chronic insufficiency is a potential outcome.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but they are at risk for developing pneumonia due to their respiratory therapy and underlying conditions.
5. Sepsis: The patient's compromised immune system and recent PEA arrest make them susceptible to sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
6. Wound complications: The patient's breast reduction surgery was complicated by incision infections, and they are now experiencing bleeding complications while on heparin. Monitor for signs of infection and bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be related to arrest-associated encephalopathy, and they are at risk for further neurological deterioration.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor nutritional intake and compromised gut function may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients.

Based on this assessment, I recommend the following plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, abdominal examination, and laboratory results to assess for further bleeding, ischemic bowel disease, and renal failure.
2. Encourage the patient to accept replacement of the nasogastric tube (NGT) to assess for upper GI bleeding.
3. Provide symptomatic relief for nausea and pain.
4. Monitor for signs of infection and bleeding at the breast incision sites and femoral central line.
5. Consider repeat bleeding scans and angiography if the patient's bleeding persists.
6. Continue to optimize pain management and encourage the patient to participate in physical therapy to prevent complications.
7. Monitor the patient's nutritional intake and consider enteral nutrition if necessary.
8. Continue to provide close monitoring and management of the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status to prevent complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who presented to the hospital with a massive pulmonary embolism (PE) and was subsequently found to have a gastrointestinal (GI) bleed and a right breast hematoma. The patient has been hemodynamically stable, but her hematocrit (HCT) has been dropping, and she has required multiple blood transfusions.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.73 g/dL
* Hematocrit (HCT): 27.0%
* Platelet count: 174,000/mm³
* White blood cell count: 9.2 x 10³/mm³
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 21 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 115 mg/dL
* Calcium: 6.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.5 mg/dL

The patient has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hypotensive event, and her kidney function is being closely monitored.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 96% on nasal cannula oxygen. Her cardiovascular status is also stable, with a blood pressure of 154/57 mmHg and a heart rate of 86 beats per minute.

The patient's neurological status is also stable, with no signs of increased intracranial pressure or neurological deficits.

The patient's GI bleed is ongoing, and she is receiving blood transfusions and IV fluids to support her blood volume. She is also receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) to reduce the risk of bleeding.

The patient's breast wound is being managed with packing and compression dressing, and she is receiving antibiotics to prevent infection.

The patient's code status is full code, and she is being followed by the plastics department for her bilateral breast reduction surgery.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

* Continued bleeding from the GI tract or breast
* Development of coagulopathy due to the ongoing blood loss and heparin therapy
* Kidney injury or failure due to ATN or other causes
* Respiratory failure due to hypoxia or other causes
* Infection or sepsis due to the GI bleed or breast wound
* Neurological deficits or increased intracranial pressure due to hypoxia or other causes

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who presented to the hospital with Lower Gastrointestinal Bleeding (LGIB) and a history of Pulmonary Embolism (PE). She has undergone an Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) filter placement and has been treated with Heparin. Her hemoglobin (Hct) levels have been decreasing, and she has had bloody bowel movements and bleeding from her right breast. A repeat RBC tagged scan showed a sigmoid bleed. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 154/57 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.2-11.6 x 10^9/L, platelet count of 174-178 x 10^9/L, and a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. Her liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Her coagulation studies show a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and an elevated international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Maintaining access via Power PICC
* Quarterly Hct checks
* GI consultation and follow-up recommendations
* CT torso scan showing a right breast hematoma and some ileal/jejunal thickening
* IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI) administration
* Type and cross 4 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs)
* LENIs today, deferring anticoagulation for now
* Restarting ACE inhibitor at a lower dose once Hct stabilizes and renal function improves

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued bleeding from the sigmoid colon and right breast
2. Development of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hypotensive event
3. Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to IVC filter placement and prolonged immobilization
4. Delayed healing of surgical wounds due to ongoing bleeding and hematoma
5. Potential for ICU delirium and short-term memory deficits due to sedation and hypoxia/hypoperfusion
6. Risk of infection due to prolonged hospitalization and invasive lines
7. Potential for gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation, due to ongoing bleeding and ileal/jejunal thickening
8. Risk of kidney injury due to hypotension and ATN
9. Potential for respiratory complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to hypoxia and hypoperfusion
